title: New York Attorney General Seeks Bill Allowing Prosecutions After Pardons
summary: Letitia James urges closing 'double-jeopardy loophole,' would apply measure only to presidential associates. title: Enterprise Tech Race Spurs M&A Deals

title: Taming Facebook, Google and Amazon
summary: They've been wildly successful-as in the Wild West.. The internet, the web, all things digital are officially in beta. Because they're in beta, everything is forgiven-there is absolution for the infelicities, the flaws and the wrongs, intended and unintended. Here we are in the midst of e-evolution, looking for a moral and intellectual GPS at a time when our phone is supposed to measure heartbeat, steps walked, stairs climbed and hours slept, but gives no true sense of perspective or place. Yet there is an awakening, and we are on the cusp of a reckoning.

title: On Climate, the Kids Are All Wrong
summary: And a band of ignorant brats shall lead them: Some things have hardly changed since 1212.. In the summer of 1212, thousands of divinely inspired young people from across Catholic France and Germany took off to liberate Jerusalem from the Muslims. None made it to the Holy Land. Many died along the way or were sold into slavery. As military campaigns go, the Children's Crusade was a disaster. Yet environmental activists and politicians are adopting the same "a child shall lead them" strategy to push their climate change agenda and its latest incarnation, the Green New Deal.

title: 'Amon Carter' Review: The Man From Fort Worth
summary: A big-as-Texas rags-to-riches story that doubles as reminder of how a single driven "doer" can shape the course of civic life.. In 1985 the Amon Carter Museum in Fort Worth, Texas, mounted a major exhibition by photographer Richard Avedon. "In the American West" offered a glimpse of the region decidedly at odds with its mythic character, featuring portraits of uncelebrated and hard-bitten people-miners, truckers, drifters and outcasts, among others. While the show drew a huge audience, it rankled many visitors, including one Fort Worth attorney who said, "I hope nobody from another country sees this. . . . It's not what the American West of today is all about." Surely, Amon Carter (1879-1955) would have agreed, given his affection for the idealized cowboys of Frederic Remington and Charles M. Russell, examples of which formed the core of his personal art collection. And yet the media mogul nicknamed "Mr. Fort Worth" would just as surely have basked in all of the attention paid to his namesake museum, in his adopted hometown.

title: Health Records Should Focus on the Patient
summary: If EHRs don't help patients, doctors or hospitals, whom are they for?. John Levinson states that "the vast majority of doctors have found that today's EHRs [electronic health records] make their work harder, slower, and in some cases less safe than the paper records of old" ("What Your Doctor Isn't Allowed to Tell You," op-ed, March 5). He goes on to cite examples of "poor EHR usability associated with patient harm." A main selling point of EHRs to patients was that their medical records would be available to doctors no matter where they were. However, interoperability between the software of different EHR vendors and different hospital systems is still far from being a reality. Even hospital administrators are telling me that despite the fact EHRs are dripping with International Classification Of Diseases and Current Procedural Terminology codes, they have not produced more billing revenue.

title: Community Banks Exploit Their Strengths
summary: Because community bankers don't have the resources of our larger peers, we are forced to innovate.. The struggles of one community bank in upstate New York, while real, don't support the broader conclusion that all small banks face a similar fate because they can't offer the technology customers want ("Small-Town Banks Crippled by High-Tech Costs," Page One, March 2). The truth is that community bankers are leaders in putting technology to work for their customers, and they have been for decades. You might be surprised to learn, for example, that the first bank to deploy home-computer banking in the early 1980s was United American, a community bank in Knoxville, Tenn. The community bank I lead was early to offer mobile banking. We provide an array of sophisticated cash-flow finance and merchant-processing tools for our own business customers as well as thousands more across the country.

title: The Secret to a Surpassingly Tender Corned Beef and Cabbage
summary: This Palestinian chef learned to make the St. Patrick's Day favorite from her Irish-American neighbors-and then made it her own with some deft spicing and a generous pour of Budweiser. IT'S HARD TO SAY how many Palestinians were living in Brooklyn in the 1970s, when Rawia Bishara arrived as a 19-year-old. But Ms. Bishara, who now runs the celebrated restaurant Tanoreen with her daughter, Jumana Bishara, knows this: "We were the first ones on our block for sure." That block, a strip of cobblestones along the waterfront in the Bay Ridge neighborhood, was a veritable United Nations. "You had the Regans on one side, the DiBellas on the other. Theo, who was Greek. Emile, the Lebanese guy no one knew was Lebanese until his mother came to visit," she reminisced on a recent afternoon at her current home, just a few blocks away.

title: Student Real-Estate Competition Builds Next Generation of Developers

title: A New York Beach House Set the Stage for Playwright John Guare
summary: The 'Six Degrees of Separation' playwright still spends summers at the man-cave home his father and friends built in 1930. John Guare, 81, is a Tony-winning playwright whose works include "The House of Blue Leaves," "Atlantic City" and "Six Degrees of Separation." His new play, "Nantucket Sleigh Ride," is at New York's Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center Theater. He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: May's Hopes of Passing Brexit Deal Fade Ahead of Crucial Vote
summary: Pound dives after attorney general's legal opinion deals a blow to May's plan. LONDON-Prime Minister Theresa May's chances of winning a crucial vote on her Brexit deal diminished sharply Tuesday after two groups of lawmakers she had hoped to win over signaled they planned to vote against it.

title: Real-Estate Startups Try Their Hand at Private-Equity Investing
summary: Some firms are adjusting business models in hopes of boosting revenue and creating new opportunities. Five months after the co-working firm Bond Collective signed a 42,000-square-foot lease in a Brooklyn office building, the property's owners flipped it for a hefty profit.

title: Companies Hire on Potential-If Only They Knew What That Meant
summary: Seeing greatness in a job candidate or current employee means everything to a company's future; why do bosses bet the wrong way so often?. It's a familiar setback: You thought you interviewed well for a job that seemed like a perfect fit. Then you were rejected.

title: Renault, Nissan, Mitsubishi Seek to Patch Up Alliance With New Board
summary: The board will be the sole body overseeing the alliance, replacing structures set up by Carlos Ghosn. YOKOHAMA, Japan-The heads of Renault SA, Nissan Motor Co. and Mitsubishi Motors Corp. on Tuesday overhauled the leadership structure of their auto-making alliance, looking for a fresh start in the wake of the arrest and dismissal of Carlos Ghosn.

title: Hudson Yards Designed to Fend Off Natural and Man-Made Disasters
summary: The city-within-a-city features accessible office towers, apartments, retail and green spaces-but is designed like a fortress. title: Fast-Growing Lab Properties Attracting New Wave of Cash
summary: Venture-capital funds poured $14.8 billion into life-science companies last year, a 33% increase from the previous year, CBRE data show. The prospect of big rent increases is drawing more large property investors to the risky but fast-growing niche of biotechnology and other life-science buildings.

title: Israeli Politicians Keep Distance From Arab Parties Before Vote
summary: Leaders from opposition parties face common foe in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, but interests diverge as elections loom. Both Benny Gantz, the front-running opposition candidate for Israeli prime minister, and Ahmad Tibi, one of Israel's most-prominent Arab politicians, are united in a quest to bring down the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

summary: Smaller companies' swings often track investor confidence in the U.S. economy. It has been a rough start to March for shares of small companies.

summary: Gold was also up 0.2% at $1,296.33 a troy ounce. LONDON-Metals prices climbed on Tuesday, rallying amid a fresh wave of trade optimism ahead of Chinese economic figures expected later in the week.

title: Why the Market Rebounded and What Comes Next
summary: Today, bulls again outnumber bears, but the optimism isn't extreme enough to suggest trouble is ahead. Thinking about why this year's stock rebound seems to have run out of steam involves coming to grips with why it happened at all.

title: China's Car Market Is Stuck in Beijing Traffic
summary: Investors hoping the government will reintroduce tax breaks to juice the car market have been disappointed so far. China's car market may not be getting too much worse, but things may not shift into a higher gear for a while either.

title: Ragged but Alive: Yazidis Emerge From Life Under ISIS
summary: Trickle of minority sect's members escape, with thousands still missing, as the U.S.-led coalition moves to end its war against extremists in Syria. HASAKAH, Syria-The boy looked like all the other ragged children emerging from the last scrap of territory controlled by Islamic State. But unlike them, eight-year-old Maher is a Yazidi-kidnapped more than four years ago by the militants during a genocidal campaign against his community.

title: A Logistics Provider Looks to AI to Keep Its Trucks on the Road
summary: NFI Industries uses data analyzed by Noodle.ai to predict when a rig's pump or cable or other component is about to fail. In the trucking industry, few things will sour a manager's mood like a mechanical failure disabling an 18-wheel rig in the middle of a big delivery. But if mechanics can predict when a pump or cable or other component is about to fail, they can avoid having a truck stuck on the side of the road

title: Volkswagen Supercharges Electric Car Push as Profits Weaken
summary: The German auto maker expects to produce 22 million electric vehicles over the next decade. WOLFSBURG, Germany- Volkswagen AG said Tuesday it will accelerate development and production of electric vehicles, increasing the German car maker's bet on new technology as profitability in China and at its core Volkswagen-brand unit is slipping.

title: Private Equity Is More Friend Than Foe to Consumer Giants
summary: Buyout firms are showing up more often as rival bidders in M&A, but they also help big brand owners like Nestlé offload troublesome assets. Global consumer companies face an increasingly powerful frenemy as they move to reshape their portfolios: private equity.

title: Brussels Jewish Museum Terrorist Sentenced to Life in Jail
summary: Mehdi Nemmouche, who was convicted of killing four people, receives the maximum possible sentence. BRUSSELS-A French-Algerian man found guilty last week of murder in a terrorist shooting at the Jewish Museum of Brussels was sentenced to life in prison, concluding the first conviction of a European who joined Islamic State in Syria and returned to stage attacks.

title: China's Night Traders Are Moving U.S. Stocks
summary: Chinese investors helped push up the shares of two U.S.-listed Chinese companies that came under attacks from American activist funds. When a U.S. activist fund accused 3½-year-old Chinese retailer Pinduoduo Inc. in November of inflating its sales, shares in the Nasdaq -listed company jumped.

title: UnitedHealth to Require Drug Rebates Go to Consumers
summary: The shift will involve employers that begin using the company's pharmacy-benefit manager, OptumRx. UnitedHealth Group Inc. said it would significantly expand a change to how it handles rebates from drugmakers by requiring new employer clients to pass them on to people who take the medications.

title: Momentum Slips for Auto Tariffs
summary: Proposed levies would hammer consumers and trigger pushback from Congress. WASHINGTON-President Trump's threat to impose tariffs on car imports is facing increasing headwinds amid congressional opposition, legal challenges and the prospect of consumer opposition.

title: K-Pop Stocks Can Still Hit the High Notes
summary: If Korean pop music can gain a fraction of its Asian popularity in the West, the companies producing it will be major beneficiaries. K-pop stocks have struck a bum note this week. Investors should still keep them in mind, as the country's cultural output builds global popularity.

title: Rubber Ducks a Deeper Slump on Trade-Deal Hopes
summary: Expectations for a U.S.-China trade deal and a cut in exports by the world's largest producers give prices a lift after a long downturn. title: Oil Inches Higher on Easing Oversupply Fears
summary: Stalling Venezuelan supplies and signs of further OPEC production cuts have bolstered prices. • Oil prices inched higher Tuesday, bolstered by tightening Venezuelan supplies and signs that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries would continue cutting output into the second half of the year, though they pared much of their early advance as analysts looked ahead to U.S. stockpile data.

title: Companies Weigh Data-Privacy Risks Ahead of Brexit
summary: A no-deal breakup between the U.K. and the EU could lead to a compliance gap with the bloc's data-protection laws. The prospect of a no-deal Brexit is creating new risks for companies that are required to comply with European data-protection rules.

title: Tesla's Musk Rebuts SEC's Motion to Hold Him in Contempt
summary: CEO insists tweet didn't violate settlement, says regulators 'embarrassed' by his criticism. Tesla Inc. Chief Executive Elon Musk on Monday pushed back against regulators, telling a federal judge he didn't violate a fraud settlement that restricted his social-media communications and suggested the government is trying to muzzle him.

title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions Against Venezuelan-Russian Bank
summary: Evrofinance Mosnarbank is accused of facilitating illicit transactions to benefit Maduro's regime.

title: White House Proposes $4.7 Trillion Budget for Fiscal 2020
summary: Proposal foresees years of deficits as defense and border funding would rise. The White House released a $4.7 trillion budget Monday that proposed sharply reducing spending on safety-net and many discretionary government programs, while boosting defense and border-protection funding, in a plan that also projected a long run of continued deficits.

title: Trump Keeps the Pressure on State Department Spending
summary: Proposed 23% cut in diplomatic and aid programs draws criticism from retired military leaders. WASHINGTON-President Trump wants to cut nearly one-fourth of the State Department's spending next year, drawing criticism from retired military officials and the Democrats who control the House.

title: Nonprofit AI Lab Alters Structure to Build Massive Computing Power
summary: OpenAI, backed by Reid Hoffman and Khosla Ventures, is adding a 'hybrid' model that can ramp up funding for ambitious projects. Nonprofit startup OpenAI launched in 2015 with the stated ambition of leading efforts to develop "artificial general intelligence," a futuristic form of AI that can surpass human capabilities in complex economic work.

title: Google Agreed to Pay $135 Million to Two Executives Accused of Sexual Harassment
summary: The disclosure of payments to Andy Rubin and Amit Singhal came in a civil shareholder lawsuit. Google agreed to pay $135 million in exit packages to two top executives who left the company after being accused of sexual harassment and covered up the reasons for their departures, according to a complaint filed in a lawsuit unsealed Monday.

title: What You Need to Know About Flying on a Boeing 737 MAX
summary: After the crash of Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302, the second for this type of plane in five months, here's what we know about that jet, and what we don't. The Boeing 737 MAX is the newest version of the aviation workhorse, offering better fuel efficiency and long range (and, to many travelers' chagrin, dense seating). Since the aircraft went into passenger service in May 2017, two have crashed, killing all on board.

title: FAA Has No Current Plans to Ground Boeing's 737 MAX
summary: Agency to mandate software fix by end of April. The Federal Aviation Administration said Monday it doesn't plan to ground Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX planes, despite concerns by other countries, passengers and airline employees after the model's second crash in less than five months.

title: May Secures Last-Minute Concessions Ahead of Crucial Brexit Vote
summary: Talks in Strasbourg, France, yield changes British leader hopes will draw support in Tuesday's key vote in Parliament. British Prime Minister Theresa May secured concessions from the European Union over her Brexit divorce deal Monday, in a last-minute push to head off a large-scale defeat when the British Parliament votes on the agreement Tuesday.
